column2: An economic and technical feasibility study on the use of coconut bio-diesel in Agalega
column180: Project also referred to as "Feasibility study on the use of coconut bio-diesel in Agalega" in Annual Report.
column183:
The MRC was approached by the Outer Islands Development Corporation (OIDC) to undertake an economic and technical feasibility study on the use of coconut bio-fuel in Agalega, based on the success achieved by some countries particularly in the pacific region.

Objectives of study:
1. To identify the most economically feasible technique for use of coconut oil as bio-fuel in Agalega (Neat, blended or Esterification into "Biodiesel")
2. To estimate the quantity of bio-fuel that can readily be produced in Agalega
3. To estimate the cost of producing bio-fuel from coconut oil in Agalega
4. To assess the cost and bnefits for the environment, human health and society
5. To prepare a technological feasibility of bio-fuel production and its likely barriers
6. To assess the energy balance in producing bio-fuel, that is, amount of energy consumed in producing bio-fuel from coconut oil relative to energy contained in bio-fuel.
7. To evaluate the impact of bio-fuel on engine performance and maintenance.

column2: Measuring teacher leadership in the Mauritian Secondary Schools
column183:
The research aim of the theme under investigation is to assess the degree of leadership skills for the most important actors of the Mauritian secondary educational system, the teachers. Since empirical research about the topic is very rare even on the international scene, not to say inexistent in Mauritius, measurement instruments will have to be designed to investigate the desired factor. Hence, through a synthesis of literature, subscales of classroom-based teacher leadership will be developed and organised into several constructs. For the purpose of our study, a sample of 480 teachers from 48 secondary schools spread over the 4 existing educational zones will be used.
The aim of the study is not merely for measurement purposes but it also has for objectives to understand how critical, leadership abilities are for the teaching jobs, to analyze the actual situation in our schools as well as to derive any solutions or recommendations in case there is serious limitation in this domain. Questionnaires to capture the general inner-feeling of the teachers self leadership skills, will be designed and distributed in all the schools involved in our research. Interviews will also be scheduled for at least 2 teachers per school, in order to delve further the subject.

This research is exploratory in nature and tries to identify the impacts and benefits of integrating AR in the teaching curriculum in Mauritius. User trials would be conducted to gather empirical evidence as a basis for validation. At least forty individuals would be taking part in the preliminary study to reflect on how AR provides a powerful and engaging visual and cognitive experience in understanding the biological sciences.
This study would be the building blocks to a larger consortium with the aim of supporting new policies on the benefits derived from integrating novel methods of Human Computer Interaction (HCI) in academia to enhance student performance. The research being at its early stages will focus on primarily introducing and exploring the benefits of AR in the University Curriculum in Mauritius. Considering factors such as cost, usability constraints and perceived affordance the study also focuses on how the technology would be adopted in the Mauritian context.

column2: Towards better understanding of the hydrodynamics and morphodynamics around fringing barrier reefs: SEMPA, Rodrigues Island, Mauritius
column183:
This research will focus on part of a lagoon surface area and part of the off lagoon situated in the Southern part Rodrigues Island, Republic of Mauritius. The region is a conservation zone whereby a Marine Portected Area (MPA) known as the South East Marine Protected Area (SEMPA) has been established. Located in the South West of the Indian Ocean, the Republic of Mauritius is also comprised of other islands such as Mauritius Island, Agalega Island and Cargados Carajos.
The established Marine Protected Area is now into regulation (Rodrigues Regional Assembly, 2011). The main aim of the SEMPA is to restore the depleted marine habitat, and also to maintain the existing marine ecological values (Kaly eta al., 2007). In order to achieve this, the SEMPA project has the innovative approach of integrating the social, economical and environmental interests of the area under concern. Thus the well being of the inhabitants bordering the SEMPA is being given vital consideration (SEMPA, 2012).
The fourth assessment report of the IPCC (2007) reports that it is likely that under accelerated sea level rise, coastal erosion will increase, and that a larger part of the population in the littoral zone will be at risk of flooding. Given these two premises,numerical modeling techniques are used in order to analyze the hydrodynamics and morphodynamics around the existing fringing reef in the South-East of Rodrigues.
This will provide a baseline in order to assist in the assessment of several present day and future management issues in the MPA. The morphodynamic model suite Delt3D (Lesser et al., 2004) will be used for the analysis. This model will be coupled with the wave driver of the Xbeach model (Roelvink et al., 2010) which has been proven to be highly efficient for wave analysis in this kind of environment (e.g. van Dongeren et al., in preparation). This will help to better understand the flow and sediment transport patterns around the fringing reef and on the reef flat up to the coast. 
The developed model will then be used to study various impacts of the predicted sea level rise on the SEMPA's coastal zone. Those may include the effects on the coastal morphodynamics, especially along the sandy beaches, the level of inundation along the coastline, or navigation safety for local fishermen.

column183:
The research project has as main objective to scientifically determine the benefit a green roof brings in promoting thermal comfort to the occupants while saving in cooling costs. As Mauritius embarks on planning its future founded on sustainability grounds, and devising policies to encourage the population to think green, techniques for optimally using land and roof space will take increasing place at the helm of green building design. The small size of Mauritius and a rising demand for land is a balance that will become harder and harder to balance, and a green roof is a technology that can help our buildings make optimal use of available space while benefitting from the other numerous advantages that this report elaborates on further.
The main focus of this research remains to demonstrate and quantify the savings in energy in the provision of a comfortable indoor environment through the installation of a green roof. However, we intend to provide a comprehensive section detailing the various benefits of a green roof including its social, economic and environmental aspects, backed by scientific findings wherever applicable. This is to show the true sustainability value of a green roof in addition to its contribution to energy efficiency.
It is true that every Mauritian would love to have a backyard garden to cultivate his/her favourite vegetables, flowers and fruits but cannot afford to do so as house space takes priority; a green roof can be just the missing link to realising this dream.

column2: Investigating the social marketing culture of NGO's in Emerging Countries: A case of Mauritius
column183:
Social marketing is the application of marketing principles and exchange to social issues. It is best known for its use in campaigns related to public health and the environment. Successful strategies dealing with obesity, tobacco consumption, family planning, safe sex, recycling, waste management and water purity are the more common applications (Kotler et al., 2002; Andreaen, 2002; Hastings, 2003). It is widely accepted that many social problems have underlying behavioral causes. As social marketing is about influencing behavioral exchange outcomes, we have witnessed dramatic growth in its use (Gordon et al., 2006). Both commercial and non-profit organisations alike are undertaking social marketing, especially in areas where educational and legal interventions have failed (Diamond and Oppenheim, 2004). It has also been pointed out that the number of international non-governmental organisations (INGOs) alone rose from 6,000 in 1990 to reach 26,000 in 1996 (The Economist, 1999) and 37,000 in 2002 (UNDP, 2002). Figures for NGOs operating at national level are much higher: Russia, for instance, is estimated to have some 277,000 NGOs and India between 1 million and 2 millions NGOs (Chicago Tribune, 2007). In 2006, it was estimated that there were some 1.5 millions NGOs in the USA alone (McGann and Johnstone, 2006). NGOs have been a positive force in domestic and international affairs, working to alleviate poverty, protect human rights, preserve the environment, and provide relief worldwide. The growth of NGOs has been to a large extent fuelled by the inability of both domestic and international institutions to respond adequately to major economic, social and political changes which have been taking place at a fast pace (Heap, 2000).
Moreover, in line with Government Programme 2012-2015, a National NGO Policy has been elaborated by the Ministry of Social Security, National Solidarity & Reform Institutions in collaboration with the Entrepreneurship Development Institute of India and NGO stakeholders in 2012. The aim of the Policy Paper was to create an enabling environment for a strengthened Government, private sector and NGO sector partnership in addressing emerging social challenges. The Policy Paper also addressed the issue of financial sustainability of NGOs through the adoption of innovative concept of social entrepreneurship and social marketing. In pursuance of the above, the Government Programme 2012-2015 mentioned that a National NGO Policy based on the innovative concept of social entrepreneurship and social marketing would be developed. It has been recommended to: 'Spearhead social entrepreneurship and social marketing culture as a way of life in the NGO sector' (NGO policy paper, page 16, 2012). Empirical evidence has demonstrated that there exist several difficulties of applying conventional marketing theory and practice in pursuit of more sustainable consumption, hence the upsurge of an adapted form of social marketing to promote greater sustainability among NGOs is emerging as a new paradigm. In the past, traditional marketing has been the only marketing method used by NGOs in Mauritius. Although social marketing has been a term for over 40 years, it has been introduced in developing countries just recently and the concept of social marketing is gaining greater momentum in emerging countries.
It should also be noted that the biggest limitation which NGOs face is the limited access to resources; they operate on very small amount of money. However, it is this limitation which has led to the development of a very innovative culture within such organisations and also, NGOs usually enjoy high levels of trust amongst people and therefore, they get trusted to go in and experiment, it is not unusual to find an NGO taking something which it right at the edge of cutting end technology and using it for a purpose. They are very quick to be in the latest place and they operate in an innovative culture within their limited resou

column2: A question answer system for the Mauritian Judiciary
column183:
The main objective of this research project is the development of an automatic Question Answer system for the Mauritian judiciary. The Judiciary is one of the three pillars of our sovereign democratic State. The Mauritian Judiciary constitutes a vital element for the functioning of our democratic system of government in upholding the rule of law and affording the necessary protection for the safeguard of the fundamental rights of the citizens. However, because of the lack of skilled and appropriately trained human resources and the lack of proper infrastructures, there are considerable delays in the disposal of cases and delivery of judgments.
The total number of cases lodged in the Republic of Mauritius has increased from 126,645 in 2011 to 147,194 in 2013. This has resulted in an increased in the total number of outstanding cases at the year of the end. Thus, we see that the number of outstanding cases had rose from 39,336 in 2011 to 50,339 in 2013.
The main objectives of the Mauritian Judiciary is to provide an easier and faster access to justice indiscriminately to all users and to reduce delays in the final disposal of cases and delivery of judgment. Unfortunately, given the above statistics, this vision is hardly being met. Delays are increasing and this is creating more and more difficulties among judges, legal practitioners and the public at large.
In this research project, we intend to build a database containing acts, cases, legal reports and other legal materials. Users (judges, magistrates, legal practitioners, Mauritian citizens, etc) will be able to ask small questions, in natural language. The system will then endeavor to analyse the query and return short answers to the users. If there are multiple answers, they will be ranked according to the priorities and displayed to the user. We believe that such a system will allow barristers and attorneys to prepare their cases in less time. Judges and magistrates will also take less time to verify all information presented to them in the courts of law. Mauritius citizens will have at their disposal a simple system which they can use to assess their position at law before seizing the courts.

column2: Environmental impacts of structural concrete using coal ash as partial fine aggregate replacement and coal fly ash as partial cement replacement

This project aims to assess the environmental impacts of structural concrete firstly when coal bottom ash is used as partial fine aggregate replacement and secondly when coal fly ash is used as partial cement replacement. The specific objectives are to evaluate the effect of coal ash on the engineering performance of concrete and the potential release of toxic constituents such as heavy metals into the environment as leachate when the concrete is exposed to humid/wet environment.
This research will be split into two parts which will be carried out concurrently. In one part, up to 40% by weight of fines will be replaced by coal bottom ash for the batching of grade 30 concrete mix. Since there are different sources of coal bottom ash on the island, samples will be collected from each of the sources for concrete batching. In the other part, concrete grade 30 will be batched with cement which has already been blended with coal fly ash. A grade 30 control mix will be also batched.
Hardened concrete samples  will consist of concrete cubes of 150mm * 150mm * 150mm and will be subjected to testing with regards to compressive strenght and other important engineering properties and to leachability tests as per EN BS12457-1:2002.
Trace metal content of the leachate will be compared against USEPA limits or relevant national standards to assess whether bottom can be safely applied in the manufacture of concrete.

column2: Identification of genetic variants of BSV among local and imported cultivars of banana and of the possible role of an insect vector
column183: The work will focus on the identification of genetic variants of BSV in different cultivars of banana in Mauritius. As has been shown elsewhere, the virus is heterogeneous. Presently no information is available on the exact nature of BSV in Mauritius and since many new cultivars have been introduced from other countries, it is possible that different strains of the virus are found locally. The virus has been transmitted experimentally using the insect vector Planococcus citri in Taiwan. Since these mealy bugs are found in Mauritius their possible role in the transmission of the disease will be investigated.

column2: Development of a processing package for pickling onion in Rodrigues
column183: In this project, research will be carried out on factors affecting processing of onion pickle. The effect of bulb size on pickling will be assessed. The bulbs weigh 2-3kg and are of diameter less than 25mm. These bulbs are characterized as unmarketable by Agricultural Marketing Board and can be used as sets and starting material in the experiment. The effect of variety will also be observed. There are three locally available varieties namely yellow, white and red type. These will be assessed for their effect on pickling. Having the bulb size and variety, the proper medium will be assessed. The result of the research will be a package for processing onion as pickle

column2: Hydroponics and semi-protected environment for the production of vegetables in Rodrigues
column183: The objective of the project is to evaluate how the new techniques of vegetable production can be used to improve the quality of vegetable produced in Rodrigues. Two new technologies will be tested with the participation of the Rodriguan agricultural officers and growers. These are semi-protected environment and hydroponics. During the running of the project, opportunity will be taken to train growers and agricultural officers in Rodrigues.

column2: The Development of a Molecular Diagnostic Tool for the Detection of Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. Dieffenbachiae, the causal agent of Anthurium Bacterial Blight.
column183: The objective of this project is to develop a nucleic acid based diagnostic method by identifying DNA sequences that would be used as primers or probes. These will then be used in the detection of the pathogens, by amplification and hybridization. The end product of the project will provide a reliable diagnostic tool for the anthurium plants as a preventive method to avoid Xad from entering our blight-free zone

column2: Investigating the common core constructs in student’s acquisition of logico-mathematical concept in physics at HSC level
column183: There s a growing need for appropriate actions to be taken in the field of pedagogy and curricular activities in the light of growing concern at policy level to improve the quality of education in our schools. Moreover, the treat of globalization and job degradation demands a new definition of our workforce. With the rapid transfer of emerging technologies, it is most imperative for our labour force to be able to adapt in a sustainable manner, to the demands imposed by the new economic order.

column2: Improving the post harvest of fresh Rodriguan limes
column183: The specific objectives of the project are to identify the technical problems to produce high quality limes in Rodrigues, to formulate solutions to resolve problems arising, to reduce post harvest decay of limes through hot water and fungicidal treatments, to determine the storage life of the produce at different harvest maturities and temperatures, to measure the respiration rate of Rodriguan limes at different temperatures, to develop a post harvest handling system for fresh limes, to train Rodriguan farmers on the production of good quality limes.

column2: Benchmarking training best practices
column19: Mr. M. Mungur & Mr. D. Gokhool
column183: This project aims to promote further development of human resources in Mauritius by identifying best practices locally and internationally, in the field of training.

column2: Rehabilitation of local banana cultivars
column183: The gingeli banana cultivar which is highly appreciated and always highly prized on the local market is becoming very scarce. The few specimens identified by the Southern Planters Association can be indexed, propagated by tissue culture and Fusarium tolerant planting material put at the disposal of interested planters for commercial production. Since the cultivar is highly prized locally, the increased production will contribute to higher revenue of the planters. Depending on its response to optimum growing conditions and the post harvest evaluation, there could be prospect for export on a niche market.

column2: Molecular Mechanisms of anti-oxidant protection in health and disease: Potential of application and characterisation of anti-oxidant actions of endemic Mauritius plant extracts.
column19: Dr. T. Bahorun & Prof. O. I. Aruoma
column183: The main aim of this project is to provide evidence that endemic Mauritian plants may be effective prophylactic agents against neurodegenerative diseases and help to reduce free radical induced teratogenesis and, the incidence of embryo malformations. Initially the levels of total phenols, phenyl chromo derivatives, flavan-3-ols and derivatives and anthocyanins present in endemic extracts will be estimated. The effects of endemic plant extracts on the levels of isoprostanes in oxidized low density lipoproteins and in plasma and urines of human volunteers will be assessed and correlated to the phenol contents.

column2: Low-Cost Equipment for Teaching and Learning Science and Technology in Primary Schools
column183: The aim of this project is to practice science in primary school. This will intrigue and delight young children, develop and expand the competence of young children across the range of human capacity and skill. Contribute to the enrichment of the whole child by extending the Childs horizons and by amplifying to his or her innate capacity and desire to question, explore experiment, discover cope and learn

column2: Mapping Educational Achievement in Mauritius
column183: This project was carried out to analyze the overall CPE,SC and HSC examinations results over a period of twenty years (1981-2001) with a view to establish a general statistical profile of educational achievement in Mauritius and to map the contemporary contextual influences on the local educational achievement configuration

column2: A Study of the Buyer Characteristics of the Green Consumers in Mauritius and their Implications for Marketing Strategy
column183: In 1996 the Mauritius research council funded a research study entitled A study of consumer behaviour in a small island economy which was carried out over a period of two years. The general objectives of this present study is to update the existing database behaviour of Mauritian consumers by observing the same people over time in order to determine changes in their consumption pattern, to establish whether these changes are attributable to individual determinants or environmental influences, to broaden the scope of the study by addressing new issues of national importance in consumer behaviour.

column2: History, Geography, Culture & Heritage of Mauritius Through Multimedia (through ICT at primary level)
column183: The main objectives of project are to provide high quality education through multimedia enhanced tools, give students the opportunity to experience a range of opinions and ideas beyond those of the teacher and the textbook.

column2: Survey of Smoking, Drinking and Illicit Drug use among Secondary school students in Mauritius
column183: The central aims of this survey are to measure the prevalence of smoking drinking and drug use among those young people and provide the basis for further monitoring of trends. Such information is vital for a coherent overall plan to help young people resist substance abuse in order to achieve their full potential in society as well as to protect our communities from drug related, anti social and criminal behaviour.

column2: Indiscipline et Violence en milieu Scolaire à Maurice
column183: This study has been carried out with objective to evaluate the extent of Indiscipline and violence in colleges in Mauritius and Rodrigues and also to propose concrete solutions to the problems.

column2: Integration of the elderly in the family
column183: Statistics released by the world bank reveal that the proportion of elderly population around the world is fast increasing. This is due to a fall in both fertility and mortality rates. The demographic trend in Mauritius is not dissimilar. The age-structure of the population is undergoing significant changes which is also the result of declining fertility and declining mortality rates. The main objective of the project is to try to find out what are the possibilities and avenues for promoting the integration of the elderly in the family, to the mutual benefit and satisfaction of all of the members of the family.

column2: Valorisation of Biopolymers (Carrageenans,alginates) from the Mauritian Marine Environment (Seaweeds and Algae)
column183: The objectives of the project are to extract, isolate and content determination of Carrageenans on laboratory scale. The influence of various processing parameters, which may affect the structure of Carrageenans. Characterization of Carrageenans and comparison with work done by other research groups.

column2: An Appraisal of the Small-Scale Agro-Industrial Sector in Rodrigues
column183: Rodrigues has a well established reputation for its traditional processed products like chillies and limes, while some of the other products, kidney beans, ham and sausages and smoked chicken are less well known. The small scale food enterprise are usually organized as a family business or have a single owner. It also noteworthy that recently two agro based enterprises have witnessed successful development and are exporting their products in the region. The small agro processing enterprises are mainly found in the agricultural areas. Hence, these small scale food enterprises have a strong backward linkage with the primary sector as suppliers of food ingredients

column2: A study of risk factors associated with suicide attempters in Mauritius -A case-control study
column23: MRC / MIH / Ministry of Social Security, National Solidarity and Senior Citizens Welfare

column2: A study of factors influencing substance abuse among young (8-18 yrs) in housing estates of Mauritius
column183: This study will entail a cross sectional survey of quantitative and qualitative nature among youth ages 8-18 living in housing estates. The housing estate will be the basic unit of study. 10 housing estates in villages and another 10 in town areas will be randomly selected using a table of random numbers. From each estates, 40 male youth ages 8-18 will be identified for a face to face interview. Hence, 800 respondents will be contacted. Interviews will be conducted by members of youth centres living in the selected estates and supervised by youth officers. The investigator will monitor the data collection exercise on a daily basis. Respondents will be interviewed from 16.00 to 19.00 hours during weekdays but from 9.00 to 16.00 hours during weekends. The study will be completed in eight months

column2: Upgrading the core work skills of the Mauritian labour force to meet the challenges of an economy undergoing rapid technological change.
column183: In this project it is proposed that foundation skills programmers existing elsewhere in the world be adapted and developed to suit the Mauritian context and realities. Trainers need to be identified with the appropriate andragogical skills, with an interest in poverty alleviation and an interest in the prevention of social exclusion. These trainers will need to be trained in the content and methodologies and pilot groups will be needed to rest the materials. Once the tools and techniques are finalized the programmed can be widely disseminated and its impact will be assessed

column2: Information systems for optimized data Management to increase the efficacy of Biodiversity Conservation efforts in Mauritius and Rodrigues
column183: The main project activity will be the development of a series of databases that permit the rapid summary of complex information relevant to conservation management. This approach has been successfully pioneered by MWF for three key bird species during a recently completed MRC-funded project. The databases produced under the MRC-funded project will be enhanced through their integration into a Geographical Information system. The goal of this project is to develop information management systems that facilitate rapid data processing to inform conservation management efforts and activities that support and enhance these efforts

column2: Sustainable Production of Palms on Marginal Lands: Optimum Sucker Population Density of Pejibaye
column183: This project is a follow up on a joint MSIRI/groupement Palmiste project which started in 1998 and ended in 2003. the Groupement Palmiste is an association of the main palm heart prodders. Annually, they currently produce about 100000 palm hearts worth MUR 20 million. They contracted MSIRI to screen new species with the objective of identifying one or more species which would not take as long to grow as the local Palmiste blanc which they currently cultivate and/or would be less susceptible to a major insect pest to which the Palmiste blanc is susceptible. By the end of the contract, three interesting species had been identified: the coconut for the dry zone, the royal palm for the intermediate zone and the Pejibaye for the humid and super humid zones

column2: Developing successful entry strategies for BPO operations in Mauritius
column19: Mr S Mungur & Mr H Abdalla
column183: The major objectives of this present project will be studying the types of BPO services outsourced and identify which ones are most suited for the Mauritian economy. Study the Mauritian environment related to BPO activities and available infrastructure. Conduct a survey in some existing companies currently providing BPO services to identify their services, gauge if they meet the required criteria such as track record in BPO, specialization in the business processes to be outsourced, available experience in the company's industry.

column2: Can the local market sustain the existing locally oriented garment production capacity.
column183: This research shall seek to address the following issues; Determining the characteristics of the garment industry in Mauritius in terms of the types of products and quantity produced for the local market. Evaluate the size of the clothing market in Mauritius. Indentify the real expressed and unexpressed needs of consumers on domestic market. Analyze the opportunities and future development prospects of the domestic-oriented firms in relation to the local market.

column2: Benchmarking for continuous improvement - A project to encourage the private sector and the higher education sector to identify and monitor benchmarks for key areas of performance
column183: This project will enhance the concept and philosophies of Self assessment and benchmarking in Mauritius. It will discuss a methodology that has been adopted and that is still being researched using the European Quality Award (EQA) framework to enable companies including the University of Mauritius (Higher Education) to establish benchmarks against the best in class companies.

column2: Effects of black tea consumption on ischaemic heart diseases among the Mauritian population
column183: The proposed study, the first of its kind, will provide clinical and biochemical data on the potential antioxidant propensities and prophylactic capacity of the Mauritian black tea against cardiovascular diseases. It is interesting to note that the proposed study will be in line with several management strategies and therapeutic approaches towards the primary prevention of and protection against cardiovascular diseases among the Mauritian population at both the Governmental and institutional levels

column2: Assessment of the use of English in International Business in Mauritius
column183: This project aims to assess the level of English used by Mauritian employees with respect to the standard required for the successful conduct of international business activities in Mauritius. The investigation will be carried out through a questionnaire, interviews, focus groups and observation/mystery shopping. Appropriate recommendations to enhance the level of English used will be made.

column2: How do Mauritian Managers manage?
column183: The current project aims at identifying the dimensions of the Mauritian management philosophies and  practices.

column2: Entrepreneurship and Marketing Strategy: The Mauritian SME under Globalization.
column183: The proposed study is planned to last for 15 months. A two stepped methodology will be used to collect data from the SMEs. Firstly exploratory research will be used to better define the problem and fine-tune the objectives of the study, and thereafter in depth face to face interviews will be used as a contact method to administer a structured questionnaire to a proportional sample of the SMEs in Mauritius. The results are expected to help in strategically sharpening the competitive edge of the SMEs for economic and social growth. Validation and dissemination of which will be done in collaboration of the Mauritius Research Council

column2: Prevalence of Substance abuse in Rodrigues 2005
column183: The main objectives of the survey are to identify the consumption patterns and trends of alcohol, tobacco and illicit drugs among a representative sample of the population of the Island of Rodrigues. The study will also investigate possible influences on smoking, drinking and drugs use other factors pertinent to those involved in monitoring substance abuse and preparing prevention and rehabilitation campaigns

column2: Study on Violence in Schools
column183: The objective of the proposal is to study the occurrence in private secondary schools, including the type of violence, and based on felt needs to prepare appropriate coping mechanisms for school staff. Violence will include both physical and psychological violence. A series of Focus group Discussion will be undertaken as part of the project. FDGs will be held with teaching and non teaching staff, as well as students of the selected private schools, the brigade de mineur and the probation services.

column2: Advanced Micro simulation of Road Traffic in congested Areas of Mauritius.
A Study on Working Time in Mauritius
column183: The main objectives of this project will be to investigate the diverse working arrangements currently in place in Mauritius, to investigate any changes in working patterns that would address any identified problems caused by or associated with working time. To investigate the opinions of key personnel representing all the industrial sectors on the viability of proposed patterns of flexible working practices and the viability of flexible working time arrangements and to investigate any differences between working time regulations ad the reality of hours worked.

column2: Study on work and Time in Mauritius
column23: MRC / Ministry of Labour and Industrial Relations/ILO

column2: Implementation and Practice of Quality Management in the tourism sector of Mauritius
column183: The main objective of this project is to investigate the existing quality management practices in the tourism industry and recommend strategies for improvement. The government is laying great emphasis on the necessity to invest in the tourism industry to make it the main pillar of our economy and calling upon all stakeholders in this sector to strive for excellence

column2: Youth Health Risk Behaviour in Mauritius/Rodrigues:Prevalence and Determinants
column183: The general objective of this study is to study the prevalence and determinants of health risk behaviour among youth aged 15 to 24 years In Mauritius and Rodrigues

column2:
Contribution of the positional candidate gene OXR1 to premature coronary heart disease and to type 2 diabetes in the Mauritian population
coronary heart disease and to type 2 diabetes in the Mauritian population
column183: The proposed project is a follow up on previous research carried out at the ex SSR centre for Medical studies & research, in collaboration with CNRS UPRES A8090 " Genetique des Maladies Multifactorielle" in Lille, and with cardiologists from the Ministry of Health. The collaborative effort left to the completion of a genome scan in Indo-Mauritian families with premature CHD and a background of T2D, in view of identifying genomic regions harbouring molecular variants underlying susceptibility to CHD and T2D.

column2: The Extent of the Progressivity of the individual Income Tax in Mauritius
column183: This study will examine the existing tax system for individuals' Income Tax in Mauritius in order to identify the pattern of the tax system and establish if the latter is equitable and fair. This is why the study will also put forward the qualities embodied as per the review of the literature-in a socially fair and equitable systems and how favourably or unfavourably Mauritius compares.

column2: The Impact of the Tax Reform for the Individual Income Tax System in Mauritius
Financial literacy:Evidence from Mauritius
column183: This study aims at determining the level of financial literacy in Mauritius and depicting any relationship between financial literacy and related issues like savings, investment, good credit management practice and sound cash flow management. It also tries to identify possible causes of financial illiteracy and to formulate policy measures to improve the level of financial. No doubt, such a study will contribute in a way or the other to the betterment of all parties concerned.

column2: Development of an Intelligent Simulator for Recycling of Organic Solid Waste by Composting
column183: The major aim of this project is to develop an adequate intelligent simulation software that can be used by researchers, private companies and government agents to design composting facilities in order to obtain good quality composts under optimum conditions. In addition, the simulator might help policy makers to evaluate composting as a treatment method for municipal solid waste, sewage sludge and other organic wastes. Such a system will end up being an important tool for the government in terms of production outcomes for composting. In other words, the government can use such a tool on an industrial basis in order to forecast the possible outcomes on composting. This toll will also be highly beneficial for industrial composting plants.

column2: Fine Mapping of a Major Yellow Spot Resistance Gene in Sugar Cane Variety M 134/75
column183: The primary goal of this work is to establish a saturated molecular map for a Mauritian sugarcane variety M 134/75 to identify genetic molecular markers closely linked to the yellow spot disease resistant gene identified in previous work. These closely linked markers could be used in marker assisted selection in order to shorten the long period of time required to select for yellow spot resistant varieties in the present breeding and selection program at MSIRI.

column2: Thematic Chronology of: Political life since 1598 to the present, of The Chinese Diaspora in Mauritius since 1654, of ‘The Age of Curiosity’ and of ‘L’Esclavage, l’Eglise et Francmaçonneries’
column180: No dissemination carried out
column183: The project will focus on the preparation for publication and the publication in Mauritius, by a publisher to be identified in each case, in conjunction with the MRC, of five politics and society of Mauritius over the years, right up to the present day.

column2: Pilot Project for Marine Environmental Education and Reef Conservation centres for beaches around Mauritius
column23: MRC / Mauritian Scuba Diving Association / Reef Conservation Mauritius
column183: The objectives of the project are to protect marine biodiversity and ecosystems by providing marine environmental education for primary school children and adequate coastal zone management and sensitization and education to the chuildren and general public, using the Pereybere public beach resource centre as a platform for carrying out these activities.

column2: An Evaluation of the Degree of Consumer Ethnocentrism in Mauritius.
column183: It has been noted that our level of imports has been rising drastically and is always higher than our  level of exports, resulting in budget deficits. By examining country of origin and ethnocentrism perceptions, this study aims at understanding Mauritian consumers' attitudes and opinions towards imported and domestic products. This study will not only help local and international producers understand the Mauritian Market but will also generate policy measures to achieve a better consumer market in Mauritius.

column2: An Evaluation of Executive Management Attitudes towards CSR as a source of business success in Marketing Practices-the case of Public Sector Companies in Mauritius.
column183: The project explores the determinants of perceived social obligations of corporate managers in Mauritius by focusing on different sectors of the Mauritian economy.

column2: Trade Unionism in Mauritius.
column183: the overall objective of the project runs in two stages; firstly, to construct a comprehensive collection of authoritative readings on trade unionism in Mauritius, and secondly, to make such a compilation widely available in book form to interested groups and to the public at large.

column2: Tracking octopus and fishes to aid the development of marine resource management strategies
column183: The aim of the project is to improve understanding of the daily and seasonal movements of octopus and several species of reed fish to assist in the development of management strategies that will protect vulnerable species and improve fishery sustainability

column2: Mapping the supply chain of broiler chicken in Mauritius to assess the impact of External threats
column183: The main objective of this project is to characterize the BCSC (broiler chicken supply chain) in terms of structure, performance and governance to better assess the likely impact of external treats on it. The project also aims at identifying the possible coping strategies of the different operators along the different marketing channels with respect to such threats and recommending appropriate measures to ensure the economic sustainability of the sector.

column2: A Study of the implementation and impact of corporate governance in Mauritius
column183: This project is an investigation of the adoption of Corporate Governance by the top 100 companies and State owned enterprises in Mauritius.  It also lists the usefulness of CSR transparency.

column2: Turning waste into wealth - Vinasse into an organic fertilizer
column183: This project will evaluate the agronomic and environmental characteristics of raw and processed vinasse, which is a waste product generated during ethanol production from sugar cane juice or molasses. It is produced in large amounts and can be a serious environmental liability if not properly disposed. This project aims at finding a potential use for this waste product, by processing it into a form that is safe, effective and easily applicable.

column2: Strategy processes and practices in changing Mauritius: A study of its local business organisations
column183: This study is inspired by the lack of information and knowledge about strategic management in Mauritius. Current research and literature is based on American and Western theory which are increasing challenge in relevance as we learn more about management in other parts of the world. Yet we have no strategy theory or evidence about what is appropriate and what works well in Mauritius for Mauritian companies and what is not appropriate.

column2: Effects of ultrasound irradiation on anaerobic digestion of solid waste
column183: The results from this study will constitute a comprehensive set of contribution to the knowledge in the field of ultrasound assisted anaerobic digestion in Mauritius and the region.

column2: A Study of Online Social Networks in Mauritius: Impact on Secondary Education
column183: Since no prior research about the usage of Online Social Networks (OSNs) by secondary students in Mauritius has been carried out so far, our first objective will be the gathering of data, both quantitative and qualitative about students’ usage of OSNs. This will be done through surveys and interviews of both students and teachers. The raw data itself will be very useful for future research works in the area since it is currently unavailable for Mauritius.

column2: Diagnostic test for Preeclampsia at SSRNH in Mauritius: Inositol Phosphoglycan - P type (IPG-P)
column23: MRC/ SSR Resource Centre Laboratory - UoM
column183: This project can be useful in screening pregnant women and identifying those who are at risk of developing preeclampsia in Mauritius, thus providing a screening test whereby women can be identified before the clinical appearance of the disease, hence giving doctors and nurses a tool for better management of the condition.

column2: Energy futures of Mauritius in a Carbon Constrained World
column183: This research will investigate alternative emission pathways for Mauritius for different atmospheric GHG stabilization levels. System Dynamics modelling is used to propose low-carbon emission scenarios over the 2050 time horizon. The basket of viable technologies will be proposed for the different low- emission scenarios, and the investment costs will be estimated. Further, the potential for ‘green’ job creation will be investigated for the low-emission pathways relative to the business-as-usual situation. As a case study, the applicability of the System Dynamics methodology to develop Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMAs) will be demonstrated for Mauritius, and a general framework for developing NAMAs will be proposed

column2: A proposal to determine the prospects for wave energy development around Mauritius
column183:
Contract has been signed on 27.04.12.  1st instalment of Rs165,000 has been disbursed.  Project is ongoing.  02.07.12.
With its increasing dependence on oil, it would seem wise for Mauritius to explore whether ocean wave energy has a role in displacing fossil fuel power generation. This is a proposal to make a cmprehensive analysis of the prospects for wave energy resource development in the seas around Mauritius. The study will have two main themes. The first, which will be the main focus of this study, is to assess what wave resource Mauritius has. The second part will use the results of the wave climate analysis in conjuction with other factors to chart a development path for a new energy industry.

column2: Strategies to manage stormwater run-off and promote recharge of underground acquifers
column183: The project aims to present a gamut of stormwater management measures for our buildings, designed for the different zones of Mauritius that have been created based on rainfall intensity. The designs will be targeted for the various types of residential and non-residential buildings in Mauritius, with consideration for various scenarios of building to site area ratio and thus the amount of open area available on-site for infiltrating the run-off. An integrated approach to buidling design will be adopted to achieve synergy between stormwater management and other sustainable practices such as irrigation, potable water reduction and recharge of underground aquifers.

column2: Monitoring of pesticide concentration in ground and surface waters
column19: Mr. K. F. Ng Kwee Kong
column183: Research on the impact of pesticides on the quality of water resources has been concentrated in countries of the temperate world. Yet the agenda of the Rio Meeting in April 1992 that concentrated on the protection of the quality and supply of fresh waster sources noted the global nature of water resource and water quality problems. There are few regions of the world that are exempt from the loss of potential sources of fresh water supply or from degraded water quality of surface and ground water sources. It is therefore of vital interest that the current state of knowledge acquired in the temperate world be extended to include the tropical conditions experienced by the developing countries including Mauritius where little information exists on the extent of pesticide contamination of water resources.

column2: Adaptive Coding Techniques for Time Varying Channels
column183: Forward error correcting codes applied to time varying channels must be designed so as to give the desired sink error rate for the worst case channel state. Thus when the channel is relatively error free, much unnecessary error control power is being used, causing a reduction in overall information rate. An adaptive coding scheme employs only the necessary degree of error correction to be applied and so improves the information's rate and through put efficiency.

column2: Nitrous Oxide erosion from soils under sugarcane in Mauritius
column19: Mr. K. F. Ng Kee Kwong
column183: Approximately 10 000 tones nitrogen (N) are applied annually over the 80 000 ha of sugar cane lands in Mauritius. Our nitrogen balance studies have shown that while leaching is not a major cause of fertilizer N loss at least under the climatic conditions in Mauritius, 40 percent or more of the fertilizer N remained unaccounted for. On account of the rising costs of N fertilizer, the N unaccounted for has been a matter of concern to agricultural researchers and producers because if affects N use efficiency and crop productivity. The unaccounted for N has now also become a matter of concern to the general population at large because of its potential detrimental effect on the environment.

In an era of rapid technological and social advancement, there is a general tendency in the consumers' habits to spend more. The project aims to find out how the socio-psychological variables, highlighted through surveys and study, will lead to an improved purchasing attitude.

Cellulose is a highly crystalline material that has found several industrial applications such as textile fibres packaging materials, in the manufacture of paper and some other biomedical applications.

column183: The short term objective is to interview Mauritian diplomats, development and trade ministry officials, and private sector businessman involved in Indian ocean commerce, financial services , banking shipping et all. This project will investigate Mauritius's diplomatic leadership over the proposed IORA and what benefits have accrued from this initiative, the potential economic benefit to Mauritius from the establishment of an Asian-like regional trading organization in the Indian ocean, and the degree to which Mauritius development model holds promise for the many less developed countries in the region.

column183: This present research proposal will deal with lead pollution in Mauritius. Our main objectives for this study are to investigate the extent of lead pollution in Mauritian soil and/or river sediments, to investigate the uptake of lead by plants in polluted areas. To monitor this pollution with time.

column183: The project assesses the extent of atmospheric pollution caused by the exhaust system of mobile internal combustion engines.  A smoke meter and gas analyser were used for assessing pollution from diesel and petrol driven vehicles, respectively.

column183: Oil lubricant monitoring is an important and useful condition monitoring method applicable to a number of industries including transport, automotive, internal combustion engines etc. the properties of the oil deteriorate. Wear particles carried away in the used lubricant can be considered to carry signature of the wear processes.

column183: An industrial pilot scale treatment plant based on the USAB system has been built at Rose Belle Sugar Factory. The major aim of the project is to start up the treatment plant during the pre milling season and to operate it during two milling seasons to determine optimum operations criteria. column2: An investigation into the level of insecticide resistance in liriomyza trifoli populations in Mauritius (Phase II)

These will be used as standards against which to evaluate the level of resistance of L.trifolli to a range of widely used insecticides, insect growth regulators and insecticide cocktails. Similar tests will be performed on L.trifolii populations from areas with different spraying intensities. Tests will be performed over a 12 month period to monitor any temporal change in resistance levels.

column183: This project aims, in the first instance, at evaluating the physical, chemical and sensory characteristics of palm shoot grown locally. This will include quantification of the edible/non edible ratio, titratable acidity, browning  reactions/blanching tests, proximate composition analysis, evaluation of the organoleptic properties. This information will be of great value to food scientists and technologists, food manufacturers and nutritionists.

column2: Use of bio-indicators for heavy metal pollution studies
column183: The project aims at constructing a marine pollution monitoring system using the concept of bio-indicators. Implicit in what is proposed is a conceptual model of the physical, biological and social systems, potentially being affected. Appropriate bio indicators of heavy metal pollution will be established by analyzing water, sediment and tissue samples of potential candidates from the coastal environment of Mauritius.

column183: The aim of this project is to determine the implications of disproportionate indebtedness as opposed to the capacity of a household to repay the debts whether this phenomenon results from an immoderate or inappropriate recourse to credit, or from a decrease in net income due to unemployment, illness etc.

column2: A study of technology and investments decision in the SME sector in Mauritius
column183: This study will aim at putting in place the role and importance of the SME sector in the future growth of Mauritius and to assess its technology investment decision making process. Based on this analysis, technology investment strategies will be formulated

column2: Validation of the commonly used medicinal plants of Mauritius
column183: Medicinal Plants form part of the cultural heritage of both Mauritius and Rodrigues. It is generally perceived however, that the use of plants is usually free of side effects as they are Natural. This is far from the truth as many side effects often accompany the indiscriminate use of plants products. This project will address this issue as these plants will be tested and their medicinal values validated. Various tests will be carried out to ascertain their curative properties. Endemic plants will also be screened for their pharmacological values.

column2: Elimination of pathogen from noble canes
column183: Saccharum officinarum, the noble sugarcane, has the quality of high sucrose and purity, but is generally susceptible to diseases. In Mauritius a collection of some 125 clones of S.officinarum is available in the field. There are serious concerns about the disease status of the clones found in the collection. Various methods of hot water treatments generally used for controlling sugarcane diseases have not been successful in freeing the canes from different pathogens. It is this envisaged to produce disease free S. officinarum clones by using tissue culture techniques coupled with thermo therapeutic treatments as well as the incorporation of antibiotics and antiviral agents on the culture media.

column2: Detection of the phytoplasma associated with yellow leaf syndrome of sugar cane
column183: In this study, a survey will be carried out to determine the distribution of the pathogens associated with Yellow leaf syndrome in Mauritius.

column2: Use of compost by farmers as an adaptation strategy for climate change: Land application and simulation studies
column183:
This study comprised analyzing different treatments namely: (a) Soil only(S), (b) Compost and
soil (SC), (c) Soil and Manure (SM), Soil and Manure(SM) and (e) Compost, Soil and Chemical
fertilizers (SFC) for comparing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. The GHG emissions were monitored and compared by quantifying CO2 and CH4 fluxes using a static flux chamber. The following chemical and physical analyses of soil properties were monitored: pH, electrical conductivity, moisture content, bulk density, porosity, water holding capacity, volatile solids, Nitrogen, Phosphorus, Potassium and Total Organic Carbon (TOC). Further investigations involved analysis of crop yield and root system formation of Lactuca Sativa seedlings (lettuce)
which were grown on each treatment. The results showed that organic treatments such as MSW compost and chicken manure addition helped to maintain the pH of soil between 7.3-7.5 which is deemed conducive for vegetation. It was also deduced that both compost and chicken manure were successful in reducing the bulk density of the soil by at least 8 %. After 7 weeks, incorporation of compost triggered an increase of 135% in the TOC of the soil while the TOC of
SM and SF increased by 108% and 86.9% only. A maximum flux of 46.41 g/m2/day of CO2 was
measured from treatment SM on the 49th day. Thus, treatment SM acted as a source of CO2.
Treatment SC was a sink for CO2, since the net fluxes of both CO2 and CH4 was zero.

column2: Assessing the impacts of climate change on the Phenology of Native Mauritian Plants
column183:
Plant phenology is defined as the scientific study of the timing of recurrent biological events (flowering, fruiting, leaf shading and leaf flushing), the causes of their timing with regard to biotic and abiotic factors, and the interrelation among phases of the same or different species. Phenology has evolved over millions of years, but ecosystems degradation and climatic changes are affecting the native flora and fauna, and phenological patterns. However, there are relatively few studies on this subject worldwide. The Mauritian Wildlife Foundation initiated a study a decade ago to understand the natural food availability throughout the year across fragmented remnants and to manage supplementary feeding, which has been formalised since 2007. Phenology data has been collected for the period September 2007 to present at five conservation
sites in Mauritius (four in the Black River Gorges National Park and the fifth, on the offshore islet of Ile aux Aigrettes) on 48 native and 16 introduced species.
Significant correlations between phenological traits (flower budding, flowering, fruiting and leafing) to month, site and individual trees in declining order have been found. Phenology calendars have been produced for 43 native and 16 introduced species and these are useful tools for conservation of the species and for studying the impacts of climate change or variability on phenology. The effects of climate change are still unknown due to the paucity of data. However, initial analysis based on a restricted data set seems to indicate that rainfall variation does not significantly affect phenological traits for native and introduced species studied here.

column2: Modelling the effect of large-scale circulation patterns and other factors on water level in reservoirs in Mauritius: A Hydroinformatics Approach
column183:
In this project, we propose to use past climatic data to develop explanatory and predictive models for a central parameter: the level of water in our reservoirs. We propose a hydroinformatics approach to develop statistical models that relate the level of water to all relevant paramaters. Besides meteorological data (precipitation, temperature, evaporation, etc.), we shall also analyse large scale circular phenomena, like El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD).
Besides traditional statistical approaches such as regression analysis, we also propose to experiment with a variety of machine learning and statistical pattern recognition tools, including artificial neural networks, support vector machines, and Markov chains. Our objective is to develop a model that uncovers the most likely hypothesis of what determines water levels. We shall focus on a couple of rerservoirs, including Mare aux Vacoas, where the drop In the water level is particularly acute and alarming. We argue that such models are crucially important because they will shed light on the underlying phenomena. A predictive model can enable medium and long-term planning and facilitate proactively measures for forecasted water shortages. An explanatory model can help in the development of robust, sustainable and effective solutions.
